0.user_question: 44857138 people are riding a bus. On the first stop, 4857138 passengers get off, and 5 times as many people as the number who got off from the bus get into the bus. On the second stop 21, passengers get off and 3 times fewer passengers get on. How many passengers are riding the bus after the second stop?

ost_step.1: Initially, there are 44,857,138 riders on the bus.

direct_answer.text:
First let’s find out how many passangers remain on the bus when it arrives at its first destination (remembering we want our answers rounded to whole numbers):  
Initial amount – Passengers getting off + new arrivals= Remaining passengers; thus…   
Passenger_count remaining / Total ride time = New passenger count per unit time interval    
Remaining_passenger_count/Total_ride_time×New_arrival_rate(people)=Peopleboardingbusperunitoftimeinterval   
For simplicity sake I am going to assume this was one hour long journey so my units simplify to hours and seconds but you can use your preferred measurement system such as minutes or half years depending upon what suits best your need. Simplified calculation yields...   
Number boarding within onehour window=(5 × Number Getting Off)≈5 × 4 85 7 1 3 8≈ 24 2 8 5 6 6+1e−7 or approx­ 24 28 5 6 7 billion − remember round down not up since fractional human doesn’t make sense! ——– >[

0.user_question: 44857138 people are riding a bus. On the first stop, 4857138 passengers get off, and 5 times as many people as the number who got off from the bus get into the bus. On the second stop 21, passengers get off and 3 times fewer passengers get on. How many passengers are riding the bus after the second stop?

ost_step.1: Initially, there are 44,857,138 riders on the bus.
ost_step.2: From the first stop, 4,857,138 leave the bus. New count becomes 44,857,138 - 4,857,138 = 39,999,000.
ost_step.3: Next, 5 * 4,857,138 = 24,285,690 new customers board at this point so that we now see 39,999,000 + 24,285,690 = 64,284,690 individuals present aboard.
ost_step.4: Upon arrival at the next station, another 21 decide to exit which brings us down to 64,284,690 - 21 = 64,284,669 participants remaining inside our vehicle for transportation purposes.

direct_answer.text: After solving it analytically using steps provided above: At initial stage we subtract those getting out (i.e., 4857138) => Total=39999000+Total(new_boarding)=24285690=>Final Count(after Second Stop)=64284669 Hence Final

1.subquestion: If John starts dividing candies among himself and seven friends equally but ends up with five extra pieces because they weren't evenly divisible, how many people altogether received an equal share including John (excluding any leftovers)?

subanswer.text: There are eight people receiving shares ('himself' plus seven friends), thus all who got an equal portion totals 8. Answer includes no calculation required regarding actual quantities here—just logical deduction about distribution groups. 0.user_question: 44857138 people are riding a bus. On the first stop, 4857138 passengers get off, and 5 times as many people as the number who got off from the bus get into the bus. On the second stop 21, passengers get off and 3 times fewer passengers get on. How many passengers are riding the bus after the second stop?

1.subquestion: How many people ride onto the bus during the first stop?

subanswer.text:
To solve this problem, we need to find out three things separately before summing them up;

At start: Number Of People Rideing Bus (NOPB) = 44857138  
Number Who Got Off At First Stop (NOGOF) = 4857138   
Passengers Getting Board Too Few(PGBTF) = NOGOF*x= NOPB/5 -> PGBTF = ((NoOfPeopleRidingBus)/5)-((NoOfpeopleGotOffFirstStop))->PGBTF=(44857138/5)-(4857138)=896818~    
Now let’s calculate Total Passenger board ship at Second stop i.e.(TBPS): TBPS = NoOFpassangersGetOnSecondstop+(NoOFFromSecondShip)*(-1) ===>Tbps+tbf==>(NoONboardsecondship)+(-NoOfpassangersFromSeondbus)->TBS=-21-3*(NoOFFROMSEcondStop)      
Total Passageboarat New totalsizeof passenger
